page.title: 14 KNOCKAGH;THE MONUMENT
page.content: Since 1924 the venerable head of the {KNOCKAGH HILL}has worn a crown. In that year a memorial to the people of County Antrim who lost their lives in the {Great War of 1914-18}was erected on the highest point of the 967 foot hill and to this day a poppy wreath is placed at its foot on Remembrance Day. The memorial is in the form of an obelisk 110 feet in height which was paid for by public subscription and constructed of a stone base surmounted by a concrete pinnacle.Facing the sea is a plaque bearing the inscription:-{ { To the Glory of God and in proud and {affectionate remembrance of the men of {County Antrim who fell in the Great {War,this memorial is erected by their {grateful County. "Nobly you fought, {your knightly virtue proved, Your {memory hallowed in the land you loved" {
